content.webTitle: Gender kissing, the age of Galileo and Keith Haring's 80s – the week in art

fields.headline: Gender kissing, the age of Galileo and Keith Haring's 80s – the week in art
fields.bodyText: Exhibition of the Week Kiss My Genders A gender-fluid blockbuster to rock your socks, with artists including Catherine Opie, Planningtorock, Christina Quarles, Victoria Sin and Del LaGrace Volcano. • Hayward Gallery, London, 12 June-8 September. Also showing Bartolomé Bermejo Intense visionary art from Renaissance Spain full of armoured angels fighting foul demons. • National Gallery, London, 12 June-29 September. Keith Haring The pop artist who created his own graphic language in 1980s New York gets the fresh look he deserves. • Tate Liverpool, 14 June-10 November. The Paper Museum: The Curious Eye of Cassiano del Pozzo This fascinating collection of scientific images from the age of Galileo includes some of the most beautiful natural history studies of all time. • Barber Institute, Birmingham, 14 June-1 September. Edouard Vuillard The parks and interiors of 1890s France seen through an eye educated by Japanese prints to mix reality and abstraction. • Holburne Museum, Bath, until 15 September. Masterpiece of the week Apollo and Daphne, by Piero del Pollaiuolo (probably 1470-80) The ancient Roman poet Ovid tells in his Metamorphoses how the god Apollo fell in love with the nymph Daphne – but she was repelled by him. She ran away until she could run no more, then prayed to be rescued. Pollaiuolo shows what happened next. Daphne is being transformed into a laurel tree. Her arms have already become leafy branches. Soon she will no longer be recognisable. Pollaiuolo gives Daphne’s metamorphosis a physical exactitude as he imagines what it would really be like to see flesh change into wood. This is one of the very earliest Renaissance attempts to revive classical mythology. It set a challenge many more artists would take up: to make the strange transformations of myth look real, from Botticelli’s fauns, to Bernini’s much more sensual Apollo and Daphne, to Picasso’s minotaur. • National Gallery, London. Image of the week Portrait of Auguste Rodin, artist unknown An eagle-eyed visitor to Madrid’s eclectic Lázaro Galdiano Museum was intrigued to find a painting of his favourite French sculptor in the collection – although the caption said it was a portrait of the King Leopold II of Belgium. A spot of detective work at home confirmed the hunch of the visitor, graphic designer Luis Pastor, and he shared his research with the museum. Happily, its curators were delighted with the fresh attribution and have congratulated Pastor on his efforts. Read more about it.
